So I finally decided to reach out because honestly things have been kind of a mess lately and I'm not really sure where to start. Like, work has been absolutely insane the past few weeks. I've got this project deadline that keeps getting pushed but somehow that makes it worse? Because now everyone's panicking and my manager's breathing down my neck constantly and I feel like no matter what I do it's not enough. I'm staying late, skipping lunch, and I still feel behind.

But like, that's not even really the worst part. The worst part is that I'm starting to get these weird anxiety things happening. Like yesterday I was just sitting at my desk and suddenly my heart was racing and I couldn't catch my breath and I genuinely thought something was wrong with me physically. Had to go to the bathroom and just breathe for like ten minutes. It was mortifying. It's happened a few times now over the past couple weeks and it's honestly terrifying because I don't know when it's going to happen next.

Anyway, my mom's been texting me asking why I haven't called and honestly I don't have the energy for that whole dynamic right now. Everything just feels very heavy. Some days I wake up and I'm just like... why am I doing this? And I don't really have a good answer.
exchanges.assistant:
**The panic attacks:** That sounds really scary—especially when you're at your desk and suddenly your body's doing something intense that you can't control. The heart racing, can't breathe feeling is terrifying, and not knowing when it'll happen next adds this whole layer of dread on top of everything else. Those sound like panic attacks, and they're not dangerous even though they feel awful. Your body's threat system is firing when there's no physical danger—it's reacting to the stress buildup. When it happens, having a tool ready can help. One thing that works for a lot of people: 5-4-3-2-1 grounding. When you feel it starting, name 5 things you can see, 4 things you can touch, 3 you can hear, 2 you can smell, 1 you can taste. It gives your brain something concrete to do instead of spiraling, and it can dial down the intensity. Worth having in your back pocket?

**Work stress:** The deadline keeps moving but the panic keeps escalating—that's a specific kind of hell. You're doing everything you can think of (staying late, skipping lunch), and it still feels like not enough. That "behind" feeling even when you're maxing out your effort? That's not about your output—that's about impossible conditions. When the goalpost keeps shifting, your nervous system never gets to rest. No wonder your body's hitting the panic button.

**Your mom:** You said you don't have energy for "that whole dynamic right now." That phrasing tells me there's a lot packed in there—something more than just not wanting to call. What is it about that dynamic that feels heavy when you're already running on empty?

**The "why am I doing this" mornings:** That question landing without a good answer is a real signal. Sometimes when we're that depleted, the bigger picture just... disappears. Everything becomes about getting through the day. What used to give you a reason to get up—what's happened to that?

Writing it down tells your brain, "I've got it, you can stop now." It won't fix the sleep immediately, but it might give you a way to interrupt the 3am spiral. Worth trying tonight?
